citation.article-title: Thermosipho affectus sp. nov., a thermophilic, anaerobic, cellulolytic bacterium isolated from a Mid-Atlantic Ridge hydrothermal vent
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thermosipho affectus sp. nov.
Thermosipho affectus (af.fec′tus. L. part. masc. adj. affectus affected with something, sensitive to external actions).
Cells are rods, 0.4–0.9 µm in width and 1.2–6.0 µm in length.
Thermophile, growing at temperatures of 37–75 °C with an optimum at 70 °C; pH range for growth from 5.6 to 8.2 with an optimum at pH 6.6.
Obligate organotroph, obtains energy by fermentation of yeast extract, beef extract, glucose, maltose, sucrose, dextrin, starch, microcrystalline cellulose (Avicel), CMC and cellulose (filter paper).
Fructose, arabinose, galactose, xylose, cellobiose, chitin, xylan, dextran, methanol, ethanol, sorbitol, mannitol, acetate, formate, pyruvate, tryptone and peptone do not support growth.
The main products of glucose fermentation are H2, CO2 and acetate.
Elemental sulphur does not stimulate growth and is reduced in the course of fermentation.
Sulphate, thiosulphate and nitrate do not influence growth, while sulfite inhibits it.
The G+C content of DNA of the type strain is 27 mol%.
The type strain is ik275marT ( = DSM 23112T = VKM B-2574T).
It was isolated from a deep-sea vent in the Rainbow Hydrothermal Field (Mid-Atlantic Ridge).
